case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Trivikram Narain Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 68 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 68 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 27, 1959 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 307 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 27, 1959 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 307 of 1957.

facts.text: The assessee is a Hindu undivided family headed by Sri Trivikram Narain Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a Hindu undivided family headed by one Sri Trivikram Narain Singh who is a descendant of one Sri Babu Ausan Singh

facts.text: Sri Trivikram Narain Singh is a descendant of Sri Babu Ausan Singh, original founder and owner of Ausanganj State in Benaras.

anchor.surface_text: Sri Trivikram Narain Singh who is a descendant of one Sri Babu Ausan Singh who was the original founder and owner of what is known as Ausanganj State in the district of Benaras.

facts.text: District of Benaras was formerly part of Oudh territory.

anchor.surface_text: The district of Benaras was formerly a part of Oudh territory.

facts.text: By a Treaty between the East India Company and Nawab Asfuddaula in or about 1775, province of Benaras ceded to British Government.

anchor.surface_text: By a Treaty between the East India Company Nawab Asfuddaula in or about the year 1775, the province of Benaras was ceded to the British Government.

facts.text: British Government granted sanad of Raj to Raja Chet Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The British Government granted a sanad of Raj to Raja Chet Singh who in turn gave the Jagir of Parganas Seyedpore and Bhittery

facts.text: Raja Chet Singh gave Jagir of Parganas Seyedpore and Bhittery in perpetuity to Babu Ausan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: who in turn gave the Jagir of Parganas Seyedpore and Bhittery in perpetuity to Babu Ausan Singh.

facts.text: In 1796 there were disputes between Babu Ausan Singh and Zamindars, referred by Collector of Benaras to Board of Revenue in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1796 there were some disputes between Babu Ausan Singh and the Zamindars in the district and the matter was referred by the Collector of Benaras to the Board of Revenue in Calcutta.

facts.text: Disputes ended in 1837 by compromise between British Government and Jagirdar Hat Narain Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The disputes between the Jagirdars and Zamindars ultimately ended in 1837 by a companypromise between the British Government and the then Jagirdar Hat Narain Singh

facts.text: British Government granted pension of Rs. 36,322/8/- to Babu Hat Narain Singh and his heirs in perpetuity.

anchor.surface_text: whereby the British Government granted a pension of Rs. 36,322/8/- to Babu Hat Narain Singh anal his heirs in perpetuity.

facts.text: Pension quantum calculated on basis of 1/4th of revenue of the Jagir.

anchor.surface_text: The quantum of this pension was calculated on the basis of 1/4th of the revenue of the Jagir.

facts.text: Letter determining pension amount Rs. 36,322/8/- dated 7th July 1837 from H. Elliot to J. Thompson.

anchor.surface_text: The letter by which the amount of pension was determined at Rs. 36,322/8/- is dated 7th of July, 1837 and was from H. Elliot Esqr., the Secretary Sadar Board of Revenue N.W.P. Allahabad, to J. Thompson Esqr., Offg. Secretary to Lt. Government, W.P

facts.text: Pension paid regularly from year to year by Government to Babu Har Narain Singh and his heirs.

anchor.surface_text: The pension was paid regularly from year to year by the Government to Babu Har Narain Singh and his heirs.

facts.text: During previous year of assessment year 1949-50, assessee received Rs. 36,396/- on account of the pension.

anchor.surface_text: During the previous year of the assessment year 1949-50, the assessee received a sum of Rs. 36,396/- on account of the aforesaid pension.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held the sum is regular annual income, not agricultural income.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, in spite of the objection of the assessee, held that it was a regular annual income of the assessee and did number fall within the category of agricultural income- tax.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who held that the alleged cash grant

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held it is agricultural income under Section 2(1).

anchor.surface_text: who held that the alleged cash grant of varying and unspecified amount received by the appellant, in relation to land revenue of Seyedpur number Tehsil of District Ghazipur, clearly fell within the definition of agricultural income under Section 2 1  of the Incometax Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer appealed to the Income- tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal held Rs. 36,396/- chargeable to tax, not agricultural income.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the sum of Rs. 36,396/- was chargeable to tax under the Act as the income was number agricultural income for although the pension was determined with respect to the quantum of the rent companylection the rent companylections or the land companyld number be said to be the immediate source of the pension.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: is directed against the judgment of the High Court in a reference under the Act, answering the question referred to it in the negative.

facts.text: High Court held right conferred was to one-fourth share in net land revenue collections.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that from the language of the letter of July 7, 1837, it was manifest that the right which was companyferred  1948  16 I.T.R. 325. was a right to a share of one-fourth in the net land revenue companylections after deducting companyts of Tahsil establishment.

facts.text: Amount received by successors varied from year to year.

anchor.surface_text: It relied on the fact that the amount which had been received by the successors of Babu Harnarain Singh varied from year to year.

facts.text: Supreme Court interpreted letter of 1837: no interest in land or land revenue acquired.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J., speaking for the Court, observed Because the annual allowance is equal to a fourth share of the net revenue of the mahals, the right of the respondent does number acquire the character of an interest in land or in land revenue.

facts.text: Allowance fixed as percentage of land revenue but percentage merely a measure.

arguments.claim: The pension is regular annual income not falling within agricultural income, arising from statutory obligation of Government; land is second degree in genealogy, immediate source is Government's obligation.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, in spite of the objection of the assessee, held that it was a regular annual income of the assessee and did number fall within the category of agricultural income- tax. He observed that in fact this income arose from a statutory obligation of the Government to pay it, and although the Government recouped this from the person with whom the land was settled, land in the genealogical tree of Malikana appears in the second degree, its immediate and effective source is the Governments statutory obligation to pay it, and this obligation is number land within the meaning of Income-tax Act, vide C.I.T.v. holdings.text: the respondent, under the arrangement, had no interest in land or in the land revenue payable in respect thereof.

anchor.surface_text: We respectfully adopt the reasoning and conclusion of this Court in the case of State of Uttar Pradesh v. Kunwar Sri Trivikram Narain Singh and hold that the respondent, under the arrangement, had no interest in land or in the land revenue payable in respect thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts prior Supreme Court interpretation of the 1837 letter in State of Uttar Pradesh v. Kunwar Sri Trivikram Narain Singh, rejecting claim of sharing collections.

holdings.text: the source of income is clearly the arrangement arrived at in 1837 and, therefore, it is not agricultural income as defined in the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies 'derived from' test via genealogy of income stopping at effective source (1837 arrangement), direct association with land, and source of right tests from Privy Council and Supreme Court precedents (Kamakhaya Singh, Bacha Guzdar, Kameshwar Singh).

holdings.text: on a true interpretation of clause viii of subsection 3 of section 4 of the indian Income-tax Act the sum of Rs. 36,396/- received by the assessee as an allowance during the previous year of the assessment year 1949-50 is revenue income liable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on a true interpretation of clause viii of subsection 3 of section 4 of the indian Income-tax Act the sum of Rs. 36,396/- received by the assessee as an allowance during the previous year of the assessment year 1949-50 is revenue income liable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reverses High Court by holding not agricultural income under s.4(3)(viii), as source not land per s.2(1)(a), via above tests.

holdings.text: where an owner of an estate exchanges a capital asset for a perpetual annuity, it is ordinarily taxable income in his hands. The position will be different if he exchanges his estate for a capital sum payable in installments.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Determines real character of payment as perpetual annuity for relinquished rights, not capital installments (no material shown); distinguishes from lump sum in parts; nomenclature irrelevant.

holdings.text: Assuming that the allowance varied from year to year, the source of the income still remains the arrangement and not land.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects variation in amount as changing source from 1837 arrangement to land.

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'derived from land': enquiry into genealogy stops at effective source; immediate source matters

precedents.citation: Mrs. Bacha Guzdar, Bombay Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 4

anchor.surface_text: Mrs. Bacha Guzdar, Bombay Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 4

precedents.case_name: CIT Bombay v Mrs Bacha Guzdar
precedents.cited_proposition: agricultural income refers to revenue by direct association with agricultural land, not indirectly via dividends etc.
precedents.cited_holding: Agricultural income as defined in the Act is intended to refer to the revenue received by direct association with the land which is used for agricultural purposes and not by indirectly extending it to cases where that revenue or part thereof changes hands either by way of distribution of dividends or otherwise.

precedents.citation: Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa 1

precedents.case_name: Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh v CIT Bihar and Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: remuneration as percentage of trust income from agricultural lands is not agricultural income; source and character altered
precedents.cited_holding: The source of the right in which a fraction of the net income of the trust is to be appropriated by the appellant as his remuneration is not in the right to receive rent or revenue of agricultural lands, but rests in the covenant in the deed to receive remuneration for management of the trust.

precedents.cited_holding: the name given to a transaction by the parties concerned does not necessarily decide the nature of the transaction ... The question always is what is the real character of the payment, not what the parties call it.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from the decisions of the Privy Council and the judgments of this Court cited above that if it is held in this case that the source of the allowance or pension is the arrangement arrived at in 1837. then the income cannot be held to be derived from land within the meaning of the definition in s. 2 1  a  of the Act. It seems to us that in this case the source of income is clearly the arrangement arrived at in 1837 and, therefore, it is not agricultural income as defined in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We respectfully adopt the reasoning and conclusion of this Court in the case of State of Uttar Pradesh v. Kunwar Sri Trivikram Narain Singh and hold that the respondent, under the arrangement, had no interest in land or in the land revenue payable in respect thereof.

It follows from the decisions of the Privy Council and the judgments of this Court cited above that if it is held in this case that the source of the allowance or pension is the arrangement arrived at in 1837. then the income cannot be held to be derived from land within the meaning of the definition in s. 2 1  a  of the Act. It seems to us that in this case the source of income is clearly the arrangement arrived at in 1837 and, therefore, it is not agricultural income as defined in the Act.
